column4: Ok, so i go and set up this computer in my office with Ubuntu and dedicate it as a server. set the group permissions, set all the people up as group members. that all worked fine but, the permissions aren't staing set. people will copy files onto the server and they become read-only for other users, so i have to go and re-apply all the permissions. any clue how to stop this from happening?
easiest thing might be just to dedicate a fat32 partition for public storage.  fat32 doesn't support permissions anyway.  Just a thought.
unop has a point.  there's a way to set the permissions mask in smb.conf for that share.  "create mode = 0766" in your [sharename]  declaration section I believe.
then sudo /etc/init.d/samba restart whenever you change smb.conf
